keyTakeAways: A daring daylight heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris resulted in the theft of high-value jewellery, estimated at €88 million.
The stolen items included a diamond and emerald necklace given by Napoleon to his wife, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and pieces previously owned by Queen Marie-Amelie.
Four masked thieves used a modified truck with a mechanical lift and power tools to break into the museum in under eight minutes.
A damaged crown from Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, indicating the thieves fled in haste.
Security failures were identified, including lack of CCTV in one in three rooms and failure of the alarm system.
Experts fear the stolen jewellery has likely been melted down into precious metals and sold abroad, reducing its value significantly.
French President Emmanuel Macron described the heist as an attack on France's heritage, underscoring the national and cultural significance of the theft.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin blamed security protocols, saying the incident damaged France’s international reputation.
Investigators suspect a team of professionals due to the speed, planning, and technical sophistication of the robbery.
The museum's curator, Laure Beccuau, emphasized that the real loss is not just financial but to France's historical and cultural heritage.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a shocking daylight heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, four masked thieves used a modified truck and power tools to break into the Galerie d'Apollon within eight minutes, stealing high-value jewellery including a necklace from Napoleon I, a tiara from Empress Eugenie, and items from Queen Marie-Amelie, valued at €88 million. Security failures — such as missing CCTV and a non-reactive alarm system — were cited by officials, with Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin criticizing the system’s lapses. French President Emmanuel Macron called the incident an attack on national heritage. Investigators believe the thieves were professionals and suspect the items have already been melted down and sold abroad. Experts warn that the real loss is not financial, but cultural, as these pieces are integral to France’s historical legacy. The stolen crown from Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, and the robbers were seen fleeing on scooters after attempting to set fire to their vehicle.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
